feed.title: NewsTracker: ebola

entry.title: Aust to close Ebola treatment centre
Football idols Zidane and Ronaldo team up in U.N. Ebola fundraiser
Football idols Zidane and Ronaldo team up in U.N. Ebola fundraiser
entry.summary: "We are delighted to play a part in helping people, communities and countries get back on their feet after the damage that Ebola has caused," Ronaldo said in a statement.

entry.title: World Health Organisation admits failings in handling of Ebola crisis
entry.summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) has admitted serious failings in its handling of the Ebola crisis and pledged reforms to enable it to do better next time, its leadership says.

entry.title: WHO admits serious failings over handling of Ebola, promises reform
entry.summary: Some critics have said that its reluctance to declare the outbreak an emergency were major factors in allowing the epidemic to balloon into the worst Ebola crisis on record, with more than 25,000 cases and 10,000 deaths.

entry.title: WHO admits failings during Ebola crisis
WHO admits failings during Ebola crisis
entry.summary: The statement listed eight lessons learned, including areas where the WHO's response to Ebola could have been better, such as information sharing and communication.

entry.title: Soldier death feared Ebola-related blamed on synthetic pot
entry.summary: Fort Hood officials say Sneed had returned the previous week from Liberia, where he helped construct an Ebola treatment camp but wasn't exposed to patients.

entry.title: Soldier death feared Ebola-related blamed on synthetic pot
entry.summary: A hazardous-materials crew assisted at the scene and Ebola tests were given has a precaution but came back negative.

entry.title: Guinea finds nine new Ebola cases near border with Sierra Leone
entry.summary: The WHO said that 17 confirmed Ebola cases had been detected in Forecariah in the week to April 12.

entry.title: Guinea finds nine new Ebola cases near border with Sierra Leone
entry.summary: Authorities launched a four day, door-to-door campaign in Forecariah on April 12 to improve community participation in reporting suspected cases and as part of an emergency 45-day drive to tackle Ebola in the west of the country.

entry.title: Guinea finds nine new Ebola cases near border with Sierra Leone
entry.summary: Sakoba Keita, national coordinator for the fight against Ebola in the West African country, said authorities had also detected 10 suspicious deaths in the community but only one of these had been confirmed as Ebola.

entry.title: Obama says Ebola-fighting goal is to prevent any new cases
entry.summary:
At Ebola's peak last year, health officials were reporting hundreds of new cases a week.

"This virus is unpredictable, we have to be vigilant and the international community has to be fully engaged in a partnership with these three countries until there are no cases of Ebola in these countries."

entry.title: Obama says Ebola-fighting goal is to prevent any new cases
entry.summary: On Capitol Hill, top government health officials echoed the president's message, saying that while recent efforts fighting Ebola have been encouraging, the threat is far from over,.

entry.title: Obama says Ebola-fighting goal is to prevent any new cases
Obama to meet West African presidents on Wednesday to discuss Ebola
Sierra Leone schools reopen after nine-month Ebola shutdown
entry.summary: "The skepticism is based on fear of Ebola because people are not very confident of sending their children if schools are not well prepared," he said.

entry.title: Sierra Leone schools reopen after long closure due to Ebola
entry.summary: Unicef has supplied schools with soap and water and thermometers to check for fever, an Ebola symptom.

entry.title: Sierra Leone schools re-open after Ebola closed for 9 months
entry.summary:
More than 8,000 schools are to reopen for about 1.8 million students and the government and U.N. children's agency promise to check temperatures regularly and will promote hand washing to discourage the spread of Ebola in the schools.

Since October 2014, UNICEF has supported the government in running daily emergency radio education programs to allow children to continue learning at home during the Ebola crisis.

entry.title: Sierra Leone schools re-open after Ebola closed for 9 months
entry.summary: "It is important that all children get into school including those who were out of school before the Ebola outbreak. Education for all is a key part of the recovery process for the country."

entry.title: Sierra Leone schools re-open after Ebola closed for 9 months
entry.summary:
UNICEF Sierra Leone says it has facilitated the training of 9,000 teachers in Ebola prevention, safety guidelines and psycho-social support.

The Ebola crisis is estimated to have infected more than 25,500 people and killed 10,587.

entry.title: Nicaragua asks US to remove embassy worker who had been in Liberia over Ebola concern
entry.summary: The U.S. embassy in Managua said in a statement that the employee was in Liberia, but denied there had been any contact with Ebola patients.

entry.title: Nicaragua Asks US to Remove Embassy Worker Over Ebola Worry
Empty Ebola Clinics in Liberia Are Seen as Misstep in U.S. Relief Effort
entry.summary:
Nine centers have never had a single Ebola patient.

"My task was to convince the international organizations, 'You don't need any more E.T.U.s,' " said Dr. Hans Rosling, a Swedish public health expert who advised Liberia's health ministry, referring to Ebola treatment units.

entry.title: Woman returns negative Ebola test
entry.summary: The woman, who has not been named, did not treat any cases of Ebola during her time in Liberia.

entry.title: Woman returns negative Ebola test
Ebola: The Fight To Reach Zero And The Road To Recovery
entry.summary:
Management Sciences for Health and International Medical Corps worked with Liberian Ministries of Health to construct Ebola treatment centers and community care centers in the affected countries.

To learn more about the NGO response and the continued efforts, listen to my segment on Fighting Ebola, an online audio series hosted by the U.S. Department of State.

entry.title: UPDATE 2-Risk of Ebola spreading to other countries appears to be falling -WHO
entry.summary: Falling Ebola cases make completing big clinical trials on experimental vaccines a challenge, with the best hope resting on a study in Guinea, Aylward said.

entry.title: West African leaders urge Ebola 'Marshall Plan'
entry.summary:
The countries at the center of the Ebola epidemic are forecast to lose 12 percent of their combined gross domestic product this year, according to World Bank estimates.

Ebola, one of the deadliest pathogens known to man, is spread through direct contact with the bodily fluids of an infected person showing symptoms such as fever or vomiting.

The conference's lead participants stressed in their closing statements the "importance of maintaining international engagement with the recovery and development process in the Ebola-affected countries."

entry.title: 'Progress' in Ebola fight, but 'substantial risks' remain: WHO
entry.summary: Such measures not only interfere with international travel and impact local economies, but also hamper Ebola response and recovery efforts because they make it more difficult for aid workers to move in and out of the affected countries, Aylward said.

entry.title: Risk of Ebola spreading to other countries appears to lessen: WHO
entry.summary: The WHO's Emergency Committee, comprising independent experts who held talks on Thursday, was "absolutely firm" in maintaining that view, said Dr. Bruce Aylward, WHO Special Representative for the Ebola Response.

entry.title: FDA modifies partial clinical hold on Tekmira Ebola study
entry.summary: The company's application to study the treatment, TKM-Ebola, remains on partial clinical hold for doses above 0.24 mg/kg per day, Tekmira said on Friday.

entry.title: Risk of Ebola spreading to other countries seen as less - WHO
entry.summary: The experts, who form WHO's Emergency Committee on Ebola, also made a strong recommendation that all countries "avoid any unnecessary interference with international trade and transport" beyond temporary restrictions already in place, Aylward said.

entry.title: UN: Ebola still global emergency despite big drop in cases
entry.summary: Other experts agreed it's too early for WHO to downgrade the status of the biggest-ever Ebola outbreak and warned the recent fall in cases may be deceptive.

entry.title: Ebola outbreak still a global emergency: WHO
entry.summary:
Dr. Bruce Aylward, who is leading WHO's Ebola response, said the decline appeared to be real, rather than just "a pothole on the bumpy road to get to zero cases."

During a press briefing in Geneva on Friday, Aylward said WHO's Ebola emergency committee believes the risk of the virus spreading globally appears to be dropping even though officials still don't know where the virus is spreading in most cases in Guinea and Sierra Leone.

He said the designation of Ebola as a global emergency is also necessary to speed up paperwork for the ongoing experimental drug and vaccine trials in West Africa.

"It is just that we are used to (seeing) large numbers of cases and deaths," said Oyewale Tomori, a Nigerian virologist who sits on WHO's Ebola emergency committee.

entry.title: Woman isolated for possible Ebola
entry.summary:
The unnamed woman returned to Australia on April 5 after working in an Ebola treatment centre in Liberia.

That country hasn't had any cases recently and she hadn't actually treated any Ebola patients.

Health officials say it's most unlikely she has Ebola and her symptoms - a fever and stomach upset - are consistent with many other conditions.

"We believe that this patient has an extremely low risk of having Ebola," he told reporters.

"Ebola is not a particularly transmissible infection under normal circumstances. It's transmitted by direct contact with bodily fluids so we are confident there is no risk to the wider community," he said.

entry.title: Woman isolated for possible Ebola
entry.summary: "Here where the patient has an extremely low risk of Ebola, we know there is no risk to the public of Ebola."

entry.title: Man in hospital for possible Ebola
entry.summary:
ACT Health Acting Chief Health Officer Dr Andrew Pengilley said he worked as a medical professional in Liberia where there had been a large number of Ebola cases.

"Due to the low number of cases in Liberia recently, the person did not treat any cases of Ebola," he said in a statement.

entry.title: Man in hospital for possible Ebola
entry.summary: Dr Pengilley said he would be treated for Ebola and until that proved negative, it would be handled as a worst-case scenario.

entry.title: American with Ebola released from U.S. hospital, aid group says
entry.summary: According to the group, their colleague was declared Ebola free after two consecutive negative tests, and has been declared no longer contagious and able to return home.

entry.title: American with Ebola released from U.S. hospital, aid group says
entry.summary: Sheila Davis, chief of Ebola response for Boston-based Partners In Health, said the group is "heartened by the news that our colleague is heading home, free of Ebola, and making his way toward a full recovery."

entry.title: Liberia watchdog says some Ebola funds unaccounted for
entry.summary: The General Auditing Commission (GAC) report covering the period from August to October 2014 analysed more than $13 million spent by the National Ebola Trust Fund (NETF).

entry.title: Only 30 new cases of Ebola reported last week: WHO
entry.summary:
The Ebola epidemic, which began in December 2013, has claimed 10,572 lives among 25,515 known cases, according to the United Nations health agency.

Ebola is still spreading in western Guinea, including the capital Conakry, but detection of the disease has improved, the WHO said.

The last known Ebola case in Liberia was a patient who died on March 27, and whose 332 contacts are being monitored but none have shown symptoms so far, it said.

Each country would retain a core capacity of high-quality Ebola treatment centers, strategically located to ensure complete geographic coverage, with additional rapid-response capacity held in reserve.

entry.title: Japanese Ebola test gives results in 11 minutes: researcher
entry.summary: If Ebola is present, DNA specific to the virus is amplified by the action of the primers.

entry.title: 30 new Ebola cases, lowest weekly figure in nearly a year: WHO
Obama discusses Ebola outbreak in West Africa with advisers
Sierra Leone police raid funeral, arrest 13 for organising unsafe burial
entry.summary:
Alimamy Kamara, head of the National Ebola Response Centre (NERC) in charge of Freetown and the surrounding area, said last week that people organising unsafe burials risked two-year jail terms.

"People should adhere to the government policy of safe and dignified burials so that we can end the high rate of transmission of the Ebola virus," he said.

entry.title: Sierra Leone's Kailahun district records first Ebola case in months
entry.summary: A ministry of health official expressed serious concern over the case, which came as the focus of local and international health officials is on the north and west of the country, the latest areas affected by Ebola.

entry.title: First Ebola-infected U.S. nurse plans to sue, says hospital didn't train her properly
entry.summary: Pham, 26, told the newspaper that chaos hit the Dallas hospital when it admitted Thomas Duncan, the first person diagnosed with Ebola in the United States after he contracted it in Liberia.

entry.title: Dallas hospital seeks dismissal of nurse's suit over Ebola
entry.summary: "Nina Pham has gone through the unprecedented challenge of being the first nurse to whom the Ebola virus was transmitted while caring for a patient with Ebola in the U.S.," the statement said.

entry.title: Eastern Sierra Leone records first Ebola case in months
entry.summary: Alex Bonapha, the Kailahun district council chairman, said it was not clear how the boy may have contracted Ebola as both his parents were healthy.

entry.title: Eastern Sierra Leone records first Ebola case in months
entry.summary:
A 9-month-old boy tested positive for Ebola after dying in Kailahun, the district on Guinea's border that recorded Sierra Leone's first Ebola case last May and was for months the epicenter of the crisis.

Nearly 3,800 people have died of Ebola in Sierra Leone but numbers of weekly cases are falling as steps to control the disease take hold.

entry.title: NSW health worker undergoes Ebola testing
Liberia, Sierra Leone gain in Ebola crisis; Guinea struggles
entry.summary: That's primarily because Ebola has yet to explode in a major Guinean city, as it did in the capitals of Sierra Leone and Liberia, said Dr. Dan Jernigan of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

entry.title: Liberia, Sierra Leone gain in Ebola crisis; Guinea struggles
entry.summary: The West African nations of Sierra Leone and Liberia both appear to be on a steady path to ending the epidemic - the wild card is Guinea, where Ebola hasn't burned as hot but remains stubbornly entrenched.

entry.title: Liberia, Sierra Leone gain in Ebola crisis; Guinea struggles
entry.summary: There are currently 62 patients in treatment in Sierra Leone, and a recent nationwide lockdown indicated there aren't hordes of hidden Ebola cases.

entry.title: Patient evaluated for Ebola at Colorado hospital after seeing symptoms
Guinea trial begins for suspected killers of Ebola workers
Medical charity says slow Ebola response killed thousands
entry.summary:
When MSF first declared there was an unprecedented Ebola outbreak at the end of March, the WHO rejected the assessment.

"We had to make horrendous decisions about who we could let into the center," said MSF coordinator Rosa Crestani, who worked at the organization's Ebola center in Monrovia, which could only be opened for 30 minutes a day because of the demand for beds.

entry.title: Sierra Leone to start laying off Ebola workers as cases fall -president
entry.summary: Guinea, which appears to be the worst affected at this time, saw an increase in the number of areas recording Ebola, with seven prefectures reporting at last one confirmed case.

entry.title: Last Cuban Ebola medics leave S.Leone, new clampdown for Easter
entry.summary:
A total of 256 Cuban medics had been mobilised in the three countries worst hit by Ebola - Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea.

The latest World Health Organization (WHO) figures published on Wednesday showed that the number of new Ebola infections in Sierra Leone fell for the fourth consecutive week.

entry.title: Ebola vaccine tests show it could 'neutralise' virus: Geneva hospital
entry.summary: There is no licensed treatment or vaccine for Ebola, and the World Health Organization last year endorsed rushing potential ones through trials in a bid to stem the epidemic still simmering in west Africa.

entry.title: Merck, NewLink Ebola vaccine appears safe, effective in new studies
10 Ebola cases found during Sierra Leone's shutdown
entry.summary: The bodies of people who have died from Ebola are particularly contagious, so they must be handled with extreme care; traditional burials, where people touch the dead, have been a major source of new infections.

entry.title: 10 Ebola cases found during Sierra Leone's shutdown
entry.summary: Hundreds of sick people were identified on Friday, Saturday and Sunday as health teams went door-to-door in an operation that also aimed to remind people how to prevent Ebola.

entry.title: 5 US aid workers monitored for Ebola in Nebraska released
entry.summary: The Omaha hospital treated three patients with Ebola last fall in its specialized biocontainment unit.

entry.title: 5 US aid workers monitored for Ebola in Nebraska released
entry.summary: (AP) - All five American aid workers being monitored in Nebraska for exposure to Ebola have completed their quarantine periods free from symptoms of the deadly virus.

entry.title: Sierra Leone Ebola lockdown exposes hundreds of suspected cases
entry.summary:
"Tests are being carried out on their blood samples, and the results will be in by Wednesday," Sisay said, adding that 173 of the patients in Freetown met an initial case definition for Ebola.

A source who declined to be identified said there were 961 death alerts nationwide during the lockdown's first two days and 495 reports of illness of which 235 were suspected Ebola.

entry.title: Sierra Leone Ebola lockdown exposes hundreds of suspected cases
Guinea shuts border with Sierra Leone in effort to end Ebola
entry.summary: Guinea sent security forces to the border on Friday night in response to reports that Sierra Leoneans were streaming over to avoid a three-day, nationwide shutdown over the weekend to help end Ebola.

entry.title: Sierra Leone Ebola lockdown exposes hundreds of suspected cases
entry.summary: Reports to authorities of sick people increased by 191 percent in Western Area, which includes the capital, during the lockdown compared with the previous weekend, said Obi Sesay of the National Ebola Response Center.

entry.title: Guinea closes border with Sierra Leone as it ramps up efforts to end Ebola
entry.summary: By contrast, Liberia currently has no Ebola patients, and Sierra Leone has seen a fairly steady decline in cases.

entry.title: American who caught Ebola improves to fair condition
3 West African countries increase fight to end Ebola
entry.summary: In Liberia, the government issued a statement Sunday warning survivors of Ebola to abstain from unprotected sex even beyond the 90-day period earlier recommended.

entry.title: 3 West African countries increase fight to end Ebola
Sierra Leoneans to stay home in final push to stop Ebola
entry.summary: A Sierra Leone Policeman guards a road block forming part of a three day country wide lockdown on movement of people due to the Ebola virus in the city of Freetown, Sierra Leone, Friday, March.

entry.title: British Ebola patient cured following experimental treatment
entry.summary: She was brought back to Britain and successfully treated at the Royal Free in north London, Britain's main centre for Ebola treatment.

entry.title: British Ebola patient cured after experimental treatment
entry.summary: The Chinese-made MIL 77 is a close relative of another experimental medicine ZMapp - which British nurse William Pooley received when he was treated at the Royal Free for Ebola last year.

entry.title: Ebola 'supervirus' is unlikely, experts say
entry.summary: The new study suggests that the Ebola virus's mutation rate in West Africa is fairly similar to that of other RNA viruses, such as rhinovirus, the virus that causes the common cold, Rasmussen said.

entry.title: Lockdown bid to stamp out Ebola
entry.summary:
Thousands of teams will fan out around the country, knocking on doors to remind people how Ebola is spread and how to prevent it.

In the hot spots - the regions around the capital, Freetown, and in the north - health workers will also search for Ebola cases.

Alfred Palo Conteh, the head of Sierra Leone's Ebola response, said a major goal of the campaign is to fight complacency, more than a year after the outbreak was declared in West Africa.

entry.title: Ebola vaccines 'appear to be safe' in tests
entry.summary: Based on the encouraging safety results, the study may now advance to the next phase of efficacy testing, in which additional volunteers are injected and assessed to see whether their immune system responds by producing anti-Ebola antibodies.

entry.title: 4 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary: None of them have been diagnosed with Ebola, but they will be isolated and monitored during the next three weeks for signs of the disease.

entry.title: Two experimental Ebola vaccines pass safety test in African trial
entry.summary: "Now we must move forward to adapt and expand the study so that ultimately we can determine whether these experimental vaccines can protect against Ebola virus disease and therefore be used in future Ebola outbreaks."

entry.title: Study finds no sign Ebola virus is mutating out of control
entry.summary:
Fauci said the findings also allay concerns raised by some last year that a rapidly changing virus could change how Ebola is transmitted, becoming airborne or respiratory.

They called it a safe, inactivated whole-virus vaccine that primes the recipient's immune system with the full complement of Ebola viral proteins and genes.

entry.title: Study finds no sign Ebola virus is mutating out of control
entry.summary: The routine genetic changes observed indicate the viral mutations are not likely to affect diagnostic testing or the effectiveness of experimental Ebola vaccines or drugs, the researchers said.

entry.title: U.S. Ebola Patient Upgraded to Serious Condition
New Ebola infections continue to drop, Guinea still a concern
entry.summary: Seventy-nine new confirmed cases of Ebola were reported in the three countries during the week.

entry.title: Guinea starts testing Merck vaccine in Ebola hotspots
entry.summary: Health workers will immunize the high-risk contacts around Ebola patients, thereby creating a "ring of immunity" around them.

entry.title: Guinea starts testing Merck vaccine in Ebola hotspots
entry.summary: But some worry about violent reactions from communities fearful about healthcare workers' intentions in a country where resistance to the anti-Ebola campaign has been strongest.

entry.title: Guinea starts testing Merck vaccine in Ebola hotspots
entry.summary: "Someone arriving with a syringe in their hand might be taken as confirmation of all the rumours going around. It's going to be very complicated," said Jerome Mouton, Guinea country director for leading anti-Ebola charity Medicins Sans Frontieres.

entry.title: Ebola survivor may have infected new Liberia case
entry.summary: Ebola is typically transmitted through contact with the blood, vomit or feces of people who are sick.

entry.title: Official: Ebola survivor may have infected new Liberia case
entry.summary: The woman tested positive for Ebola on Friday, and her case has caused concern because she didn't seem to be linked to any of the people on an Ebola contacts list and said she did not travel to an infected country.

entry.title: Official: Ebola survivor may have infected new Liberia case
entry.summary: Even though sexual transmission of Ebola has not yet been documented, it may be possible.

entry.title: Official: Ebola survivor may have infected new Liberia case
entry.summary: Dr. Francis Kateh, acting head of Liberia's Ebola Case Management Team, said Tuesday that samples have been taken from the boyfriend for testing.

entry.title: Official: Ebola survivor may have infected new Liberia case
Official: Ebola survivor may have infected new Liberia case
entry.summary: Survivors of Ebola are not generally considered contagious, but the virus lingers in semen.

entry.title: A year after Ebola discovered, relapses seen in fight to end it
WHO denies politics swayed Ebola emergency declaration
entry.summary:
In this photo taken on Friday, Feb. 27, 2015, Health workers carry the remains of a person that they suspect died from the Ebola virus near the village of Gbah on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

In this photo taken on Friday, Feb. 27, 2015, a man holds a poster showing symptoms of the Ebola virus in Kambia, Sierra Leone.

entry.title: A year after Ebola discovered, relapses seen in fight to end it
entry.summary:
Three doctors were discovered to be infected with Ebola at a hospital in Guinea's capital Conakry last week in what health reports and government officials blamed on a failure to implement basic measures for infection control.

"People are slacking up. The new cases are all to do with the violation of rules - contacts leaving their homes, unsafe burials," said an official in Sierra Leone's Ebola response team, explaining the decision to implement a lockdown.

entry.title: WHO denies politics swayed Ebola emergency declaration
entry.summary: In this photo taken on Wednesday, March 11, 2015, health workers walk past graves after they buried a person that they suspect died from the Ebola virus on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

entry.title: WHO denies politics swayed Ebola emergency declaration
entry.summary:
A year after WHO declared that Ebola had been found in Guinea, the agency is on the defensive over reports that it dragged its feet when raising the international alarm over the disease.

A June 10 memo sent to WHO Director-General Dr. Margaret Chan says declaring an emergency - or convening a committee to discuss the issue - could be seen as a "hostile act" by Ebola-affected countries.

entry.title: WHO denies politics swayed Ebola emergency declaration
entry.summary: Ebola was judged to have become a health emergency with international implications nearly a month earlier by the U.S. Centers for Disease Prevention and Control.

entry.title: Trial begins in Guinea for suspects accused of killing journalists and Ebola workers
entry.summary:
The trial highlights the challenges health workers faced in this Ebola outbreak that has claimed more than 10,000 lives, mostly in the impoverished West African nations of Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia.

The killings happened when a delegation of health care workers, including top health officials from the nearby town, visited Womey last September to raise awareness about how to combat Ebola.

entry.title: Slow Ebola response cost thousands of lives, MSF says
Roll over Ebola: measles is the deadly new threat
entry.summary:
Yet with Liberia emerging from the worst outbreak in history a year to the day since Ebola was first identified in west Africa, the slum-dwellers are facing an even deadlier threat -- the measles virus.

Researchers forecast that on top of the 7,000 measles deaths that the countries would normally anticipate, up to 16,000 additional children could die from measles thanks to Ebola-related disruptions to healthcare.

entry.title: Ebola orphans need Australia's help: Plan
entry.summary: Plan International Australia says Ebola still claims 26 lives every day in Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea.

entry.title: Ebola outbreak reached catastrophic scale due to slow global response: MSF
entry.summary: Medecins Sans Frontieres, which is also known as Doctors Without Borders, released the report to co-incide with the year anniversary of the recognition that Ebola had broken out in Guinea, a part of Africa that had never before dealt with the disease.

entry.title: Slow global reponse to Ebola outbreak caused thousands of 'avoidable' deaths, MSF says
entry.summary: "For the Ebola outbreak to spiral this far out of control required many institutions to fail. And they did, with tragic and avoidable consequences," says Christopher Stokes, general director of the doctors' group.

entry.title: Slow global reponse to Ebola outbreak caused thousands of 'avoidable' deaths, MSF says
entry.summary: Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF), which first raised the alarm over Ebola, said in a report that everyone from national governments to the World Health Organization (WHO) had created bottlenecks that prevented the epidemic being quickly snuffed out.

entry.title: Slow Ebola response cost thousands of lives: MSF
entry.summary:
"The Ebola outbreak has often been described as a perfect storm: a cross-border epidemic in countries with weak public health systems that had never seen Ebola before," Christopher Stokes, MSF's general director, said in the report.

However, Guinea recently reported a doubling of cases in a month, Sierra Leone has a whole neighborhood under quarantine and Liberia announced on Friday its first new case 16 days after its last Ebola patient was released.

entry.title: Doctors Without Borders slams global response to Ebola
entry.summary:
Particularly in the early months, it therefore fell to MSF to carry much of the response, but the organisation had only 40 staff with experience of Ebola when the outbreak began.

It was only when a US doctor and Spanish nurse were diagnosed with Ebola that the world woke up to the threat, MSF said.

entry.title: Liberians overcome fear to volunteer for Ebola vaccine trial
entry.summary: Liberians are overcoming their fears of Ebola to volunteer for a vaccine trial.

entry.title: Liberians overcome fear to volunteer for Ebola vaccine trial
entry.summary:
In Liberia, scientists have fanned out across the country to explain the studies and reduce the fear and confusion that have stymied efforts to contain Ebola.

Similarly, in Guinea, authorities started the study by injecting a series of prominent officials, including the head of the country's Ebola response.

A community chalkboard at a busy intersection in Monrovia recently read: "Ebola vaccines 1 vs. Public fear 4."

entry.title: Liberians overcome fear to volunteer for Ebola vaccine trial
entry.summary:
In addition to vaccinating about 1,500 health workers, investigators will test vaccines by offering injections to whole communities around select Ebola cases as early as this week.

That will require getting a high-level of participation; about 60 percent compliance is hoped for, said Dr. Marie-Paule Kieny, who leads Ebola vaccine research at the World Health Organization.

entry.title: Sierra Leone orders Ebola lockdown
entry.summary:
"I have made my personal commitment to do whatever it takes to get to zero Ebola infections and I call on every Sierra Leonean in every community to pull together."

"The economic development of our country and the lives of our people continue to be threatened by the ongoing presence of Ebola in Sierra Leone. The future of our country and the aspirations of our children are at stake," Mr Koroma said.

entry.title: Liberia reports first Ebola infection in a month
entry.summary: A source close to the case, speaking to AFP on condition of anonymity, said the woman was the wife of a cured Ebola patient.

entry.title: Liberia officials: New patient tests positive for Ebola
entry.summary: Tolbert Nyenswah, who runs Liberia's Ebola response, also said he had been told the test result was positive.

entry.title: Liberia officials: New patient tests positive for Ebola
entry.summary:
But since it discharged its last case on March 5, it was counting down the 42 days countries must wait before being declared Ebola-free.

The Ebola virus can be found in the semen of survivors for up to three months, and health authorities recommend that survivors abstain from sex during that period.

Although hopes were high that Liberia had beaten Ebola, officials knew that until two neighboring countries - Sierra Leone and Guinea - also beat the disease, Liberia would remain at risk.

entry.title: Liberia reports first new case of Ebola in weeks
entry.summary:
Liberian Information Minister Lewis Brown said that a 44-year-old woman had been transferred to the ELWA Ebola treatment unit in the capital Monrovia after testing positive for the virus.

In Liberia, the government had hoped to declare the country Ebola-free next month, 42 days after the last patient tested negative for a second time, which would mark double the length of the virus's incubation period.

entry.title: Liberia reports first new case of Ebola in weeks
Liberia officials: New patient tests positive for Ebola
entry.summary: Now, a new patient has tested positive, said Dr. Francis Kateh, the acting head of the country's Ebola Incident Management Team.

entry.title: Emails: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency
entry.summary: On June 4, scientist Lucien Manga wrote to Briand to tell her senior staff in Africa had proposed declaring the Ebola outbreak a global emergency.

entry.title: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency on economic, political grounds: emails
entry.summary:
Britain, China, the U.S. and others all built Ebola clinics in West Africa, but many weren't ready until late fall - after the epidemic's peak.

By the end of August, the biggest Ebola hospital run by Doctors Without Borders in the Liberian capital could only open for 30 minutes every morning and people were dying on the ground outside the gates.

entry.title: World Health Organisation 'intentionally delayed declaring Ebola emergency'
entry.summary: WHO official Stella Chungong said she was very worried, warning in an email that terrified health workers might abandon Donka Hospital and that new Ebola cases were coming out of nowhere.

entry.title: Emails: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency
entry.summary: It was around that time that West Africa's Ebola epidemic surpassed the previous largest outbreak, in Uganda, where it infected 425 people in 2000 and killed about half.

entry.title: 5 key findings from AP's story on WHO and the Ebola outbreak
entry.summary: 4, 2014 file photo, people watch as a health worker, right, sprays a man suspected of dying from Ebola with disinfectant chemicals in Monrovia, Liberia.

entry.title: Emails: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency
entry.summary: When aid agency Doctors Without Borders warned Ebola was spiraling out of control, WHO contradicted it, even as WHO's own scientists called for backup.

entry.title: Claims UN resisted Ebola declaration
entry.summary:
The Ebola outbreak erupted at a difficult time for the agency.

Britain and France also pledged to build Ebola clinics; China sent a 59-person lab team and Cuba sent more than 400 health workers.

entry.title: Emails: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency
entry.summary:
Fellow responders said many lacked Ebola experience; one WHO consultant who got infected with Ebola broke his own agency's protocol, putting others at risk and getting WHO kicked out of a hotel, the AP found.

In an email Thursday, WHO said: "People often confuse the declaration of a Public Health Emergency of International Concern with our operational response. It is very different. WHO mounted a strong operational response a year ago when we were notified the outbreak was Ebola."

entry.title: 5 key findings from AP's story on WHO and the Ebola outbreak
entry.summary: An Ebola-infected WHO consultant in Sierra Leone violated WHO health protocols, creating a rift with Doctors Without Borders that was only resolved when WHO was thrown out of a shared hotel.

entry.title: Emails: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency
entry.summary:
"I told her, 'Dr. Chan, the Ebola epidemic in West Africa is out of control,'" Liu recalled telling Chan in a July 30 meeting in Geneva.

The emergency was eventually declared on August 8, by which point nearly 1,000 people had already died from Ebola.

entry.title: 5 key findings from AP's story on WHO and the Ebola outbreak
entry.summary: Internal emails and documents suggest the U.N. health agency was afraid of provoking conflict with the Ebola-stricken countries and wary that a declaration could interfere with the economy and the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca.

entry.title: Emails reveal WHO delayed declaring Ebola emergency due to political considerations
entry.summary:
In mid-April, an experienced Ebola expert with WHO's Africa office wrote to Geneva, with disturbing news that many staffers at a leading hospital in Guinea had been exposed to the virus.

WHO's Ebola response leader, Dr. Bruce Aylward, couldn't say whether an earlier declaration would have made a difference, noting that "the overall response slowed down" after the emergency was declared.

entry.title: Emails show UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency on economic, political grounds
Sierra Leone to lock down Ebola hotspots next week: officials
entry.summary:
The number of Ebola cases in the region has fallen in recent months, though a spike in Guinea highlights the risk of complacency, over a year into the worst outbreak on record.

The rains are due to begin in May. The World Health Organization has said they could greatly complicate the fight against Ebola by washing away roads and making it harder for aid and healthcare workers to get to affected areas.

The latest figures issued by the WHO showed that there had been 10,216 confirmed, probable and suspected deaths from Ebola in West Africa.

entry.title: Sierra Leone to lock down Ebola hotspots next week: officials
entry.summary: Guinea, where the outbreak was first identified, has recorded 2,231 confirmed and probable deaths from Ebola but has seen a recent spike, with the number of patients more than doubling since last month.

entry.title: Healthcare worker in Nebraska tests negative for Ebola
entry.summary: The individual has returned to a housing facility near the medical center where the four other individuals are being monitored for the remainder of the 21-day Ebola incubation period.

entry.title: Ebola: Sierra Leone plans second lockdown to stem epidemic
entry.summary: Authorities hope the lockdown will set the country back on course to meet a mid-April deadline for eradicating Ebola, as announced by the leaders of Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone in February.

entry.title: Liberia: Families of health workers killed by Ebola get $5k
entry.summary: So far, 11 families have received $5,000 each, said Tolbert Nyenswah, who leads the government's Ebola response; dozens more payments are in the works.

entry.title: Liberia begins making $5,000 payments to families of health workers who died of Ebola
entry.summary: Ebola, often called the caregivers' disease, has decimated the ranks of doctors and nurses in the three countries hardest hit in this outbreak: Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone.

entry.title: Guinea says number of Ebola patients more than doubles since Feb
entry.summary: But there is still resistance to the anti-Ebola effort in Guinea, which is struggling to control the outbreak and has overtaken Sierra Leone as the main hub for transmission.

entry.title: Guinea says number of Ebola patients more than doubles since Feb
entry.summary:
Dr Rafiou Diallo, a spokesman for Guinea's health ministry, said there were 91 suspected and confirmed Ebola patients in treatment centers compared with just 39 in February.

The number of Ebola cases in Guinea peaked in late December when there were nearly double current number of patients at 171, according to the World Health Organisation.

Unlike Liberia and Sierra Leone, the other two worst hit nations where U.S. and British military forces deployed to support the fight against Ebola, Guinea has not seen a large scale foreign military intervention.

entry.title: Two more U.S. healthcare workers repatriated for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary: Neither of the two healthcare workers brought back Wednesday has tested positive for Ebola, but they are being monitored because they might have been exposed to a colleague who has contracted it.

entry.title: 2 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary: All are connected to an unidentified American who returned to the U.S. last week after he came down with Ebola.

entry.title: Sierra Leone plans another three-day, countrywide shutdown to stop Ebola's spread
entry.summary: The shutdown is expected to take place March 27 through 29, according to Patrick Fatoma, another official with the Ebola response center.

entry.title: Sierra Leone plans another shutdown to stop Ebola's spread
entry.summary: Sierra Leone is "hoping it will be the last push to end Ebola outbreak. We want it to be community-owned and for people to do the proper things," said Fatoma.

entry.title: Sierra Leone plans another shutdown to stop Ebola's spread
entry.summary: In what Sierra Leone hopes will be a final push to zero cases, Alfred Palo Conteh, head of the country's Ebola response, said Wednesday that the government will again ask residents to stay in their homes for three days.

entry.title: Sierra Leone plans another 3-day shutdown to stop Ebola's spread
entry.summary: The West Africa Ebola outbreak that has killed more than 10,000 people is declining but the disease has remained stubbornly entrenched in parts of Guinea and Sierra Leone.

entry.title: FDA panel to discuss Ebola vaccine development in May
entry.summary: Mapp Biopharmaceutical's ZMapp and a compound from Tekmira Pharmaceuticals Corp have so far shown they could cure non-human primates given injections of Ebola virus.

entry.title: Guinea Ebola cases rise; three doctors infected
entry.summary:
Ending Ebola could reboot Guinea's mining-dependent economy that has been hammered by the outbreak, which has scared investors, he said.

A big source of concern is a chain of new infections that can be linked back to a woman who died of Ebola and was not buried safely, according to Fatoumata Lejeune-Kaba, spokeswoman for the U.N.'s Ebola emergency response mission UNMEER.

entry.title: Guinea sees 'major setback' as new Ebola cases spike
entry.summary:
Guinea has suffered a setback in its fight against Ebola with a rash of new cases, including three doctors infected by the virus, with officials blaming weak surveillance and a failure to follow safety procedures.

Guinea officials said the new cases came from high risk Ebola contacts who had left Forecariah and developed symptoms elsewhere, pointing to poor surveillance.

entry.title: Guinea Ebola cases rise, three doctors infected
entry.summary:
Sakoba Keita, Guinea's anti-Ebola task force coordinator, said on Tuesday that the government was putting in place new measures including strict rules regulating the movement of corpses and contact tracing.

"There are numerous gaps in the Ebola response in Guinea, notably in surveillance of contacts, and that explains the difficulty in making any lasting progress towards ending the epidemic," said a spokesman for medical charity MSF.

entry.title: 4 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary: On Tuesday, March 17, 2015, health officials said four more medical aid workers have been flown from West Africa to the United States, for monitoring for Ebola.

entry.title: 4 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary:
But all are connected to - or had direct physical contact with - another American who came down with Ebola last week in Africa.

Since last summer, several U.S. aid workers have gotten Ebola and have been flown back to the U.S. for care.

But medical superintendent Dr. Peter George said the hospital hasn't had any Ebola cases for quite some time.

entry.title: Another four U.S. Ebola aid workers flown back to U.S. for monitoring
entry.summary: They are all undergoing monitoring for Ebola in self-imposed isolation as they wait out the remainder of the 21-day Ebola incubation period.

entry.title: 4 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
U.S. Ebola patient now in critical condition: NIH
entry.summary: The healthcare workers will voluntarily isolate themselves during the remainder of the 21-day Ebola incubation period, Partners in Health said.

entry.title: American Ebola patient takes a turn for the worse
entry.summary: -- An American health care worker who contracted Ebola while volunteering in a Sierra Leone treatment unit has been downgraded to critical condition at the National Institutes of Health, doctors said Monday.

entry.title: Americans exposed to Ebola return for monitoring
entry.summary: "At this point, this person has not tested positive for the Ebola virus," Phil Smith, M.D., medical director of the unit, said in a statement Monday.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola now in critical condition
entry.summary: One of those being monitored in Nebraska has developed symptoms of Ebola and was being moved to an isolation unit, hospital officials said in a news release Monday.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola now in critical condition
entry.summary: The latest NIH patient is the 11th person with Ebola to be treated in the U.S. Two patients in the U.S. have died: a man treated in Dallas after contracting the virus in Africa and a doctor evacuated from Africa to Nebraska when he was already critically ill.

entry.title: Four Americans arrive in Nebraska to be monitored for Ebola virus
entry.summary: The individuals arrived on Saturday and are being housed on the University of Nebraska Medical Center campus in Omaha, where medical personnel will monitor them for 21 days for any Ebola symptoms, hospital spokesman Taylor Wilson said.

entry.title: 10 Americans evacuated from Sierra Leone to be monitored for Ebola
entry.summary: Ten health care workers with a Boston-based nonprofit organization responding to Sierra Leone's Ebola outbreak are to be evacuated to the United States after one of their colleagues was infected with the deadly disease.

entry.title: 10 US charity staff to leave Sierra Leone amid Ebola scare
entry.summary: On March 11, a Partners in Health medical worker in Sierra Leone tested positive for Ebola, and the 10 fellow workers "came to the aid of their ailing colleague," the organization's statement said.

entry.title: 10 US charity staff to leave Sierra Leone amid Ebola scare
entry.summary:
Partners in Health said in a statement Saturday that the 10, the largest group to be evacuated to the United States over possible Ebola exposure, would travel on non-commercial aircraft and be isolated in Ebola treatment facilities.

The 10 have not shown signs of Ebola and Partners in Health said the evacuations were ordered "out of an abundance of caution."

"They will remain in isolation near designated U.S. Ebola treatment facilities to ensure access to rapid testing and treatment in the unlikely instance that any become symptomatic," the group's statement said.

In both countries there are still regular attacks against Western aid workers and officials are unable to track where the Ebola virus is spreading.

entry.title: Americans evacuated after possible Ebola contact
entry.summary: Another aid worker, who was showing signs of illness, arrived in the US on Friday evening, hours after a colleague with Ebola was flown from Sierra Leone to the clinical centre of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland.

entry.title: Americans evacuated after possible Ebola contact
entry.summary:
The World Health Organisation says its tally of Ebola deaths has passed 10,000, mostly in West Africa.

The workers served at an Ebola treatment unit run by the US charity Partners in Health in the Port Loko district in northern Sierra Leone.

entry.title: Americans evacuated after possible Ebola contact
Ebola: at least 10 US citizens possibly exposed to be flown back from Africa
entry.summary: The CDC said one patient was being sent to Emory University Hospital's special isolation unit, where several Ebola patients have already been treated.

entry.title: At least 10 Americans being flown to U.S. after possible Ebola exposure
entry.summary: CDC spokesman Thomas Skinner said 10 people who may have been exposed to the unidentified Ebola patient or who had a similar exposure to the virus as the patient were being flown to the United States.

entry.title: U.S. healthcare worker with Ebola in 'serious' condition, NIH says
entry.summary:
The National Institutes of Health said the U.S. Ebola patient was flown into the United States earlier on Friday and admitted to the NIH's high-security containment facility in Maryland.

The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said another American volunteering in Sierra Leone had "potential exposure" to that patient and was being transported to the Atlanta area to be near Emory University Hospital, which has treated other Ebola patients.

The developments followed a relatively quiet period for Ebola in the United States, a reminder that while the spread of the virus has eased somewhat in West Africa, it still remains dangerous.

The CDC said that as a result of the latest case it is working to trace the contacts of volunteers combating Ebola in Sierra Leone, including several other Americans, who may have been exposed to the healthcare worker now at the NIH.

A British healthcare worker who tested positive for Ebola while in Sierra Leone was flown back this week to Britain, along with four others who are being monitored for possible infection.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola arrives at Maryland hospital
entry.summary: The center's Special Clinical Studies Unit is staffed by specialists in infectious disease and critical care and is designed to prevent the spread of highly contagious viruses, including Ebola.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola in Africa arrives at hospital in Maryland for treatment
entry.summary:
The patient is the 11th person with Ebola to be treated in the U.S. and the second admitted to the NIH Clinical Center.

None of the volunteers in Sierra Leone who had contact with the NIH patient have tested positive for Ebola.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola arrives at Maryland hospital
News24.com | American with Ebola to be treated in US
entry.summary: Bethesda - An American health worker who contracted Ebola while volunteering in Africa will be admitted to a hospital at the National Institutes of Health, the agency announced on Thursday.

entry.title: Nancy Snyderman leaves NBC after Ebola controversy
entry.summary: "Covering the Ebola epidemic last fall in Liberia, and then becoming part of the story upon my return to the U.S., contributed to my decision that now is the time to return to academic medicine.

entry.title: Liberia's last Ebola patient leaves treatment center
entry.summary: Resistance to Ebola containment efforts also continues to be a problem in Guinea and Sierra Leone, which have both reported numerous "security incidents" or other forms of refusal to cooperate.

entry.title: Liberia releases last Ebola patient
Last Ebola patient is released in Liberia
entry.summary:
Ebola patient Beatrice Yardolo, center, leaves the Chinese Ebola treatment center were she was treated, surrounded by Ebola health workers on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia, Thursday, March 5, 2015.

Yardolo's release brings Liberia hope after about a year of battling the deadly Ebola virus, which killed more than 4,100 people in this West African country.

entry.title: Last Ebola patient is released in Liberia
entry.summary: Liberia released its last Ebola patient, a 58-year old English teacher, from a treatment center in the capital on Thursday, beginning its countdown to being declared Ebola free.

entry.title: WHO to begin large-scale testing of Ebola vaccine in Guinea
entry.summary: LONDON (AP) - The World Health Organization will start large-scale testing of an experimental Ebola vaccine in Guinea on Saturday to see how effective it might be in preventing future outbreaks of the deadly virus.

entry.title: Liberia begins countdown to Ebola-free status as final patient released
entry.summary:
Yardolo said she had been admitted to the Chinese-run Ebola treatment center in the Paynesville district of Monrovia on Feb. 18.

The St. Paul's Bridge community where she resides and teaches had become the last "hotspot" for Ebola cases in Monrovia.

Liberian President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf has said no country can be declared Ebola-free until all the other countries have no cases.

entry.title: WHO to begin large-scale testing of Ebola vaccine in Guinea
entry.summary:
WHO also said unsafe traditional burials - a high-risk factor for Ebola transmission - continue to occur in both Guinea and Sierra Leone, and health workers in those countries are still being attacked by those wary of their efforts.

Officials also said the number of Ebola deaths taking place outside of hospitals still remains high in Guinea and Sierra Leone, "suggesting that the need for early isolation and treatment is not yet understood, accepted or acted upon."

entry.title: WHO to begin large-scale testing of Ebola vaccine in Guinea
entry.summary:
The West African nations of Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been hardest hit in the yearlong Ebola outbreak, which is estimated to have left more than 9,800 people dead.

In a statement Thursday, the U.N. health agency said the vaccine study will focus on Basse Guinee, the region that has Guinea's most Ebola cases.

The agency said the spread of Ebola remains "widespread" in Sierra Leone and noted that cases have jumped both there and in Guinea.

entry.title: Liberia releases last Ebola patient
entry.summary:
There are no other confirmed cases of Ebola in the country, and as such Liberia can begin to count up to 42 days to be declared Ebola free in keeping with World Health Organization protocols and standards, Nyenswah said Wednesday.

The health agency's vaccination strategy in Guinea aims to create a buffer zone around an Ebola case to prevent its further spread.

entry.title: World Health Organization to test Ebola vaccine in Guinea, aims to find and stop linked cases
entry.summary: It will take 42 days of no new cases for Liberia to be declared Ebola-free by WHO standards.

entry.title: After Ebola ban, N. Korea opens marathon to foreigners
entry.summary: TOKYO (AP) " After lifting travel restrictions it imposed because of concerns over the Ebola virus, North Korea says foreigners can now take part in one of its most popular tourist events " the annual Pyongyang marathon, a travel agency said Thursday.

entry.title: After lifting Ebola ban, North Korea now says foreigners welcome to run in Pyongyang marathon
entry.summary: Even though no cases of Ebola had been reported anywhere near North Korea, the country shut out foreign tourists in October with some of the strictest Ebola regulations in the world, including saying that only local runners would be allowed into the marathon in April.

entry.title: Ohio bridal shop linked to Ebola survivor will sell building
entry.summary: Dallas nurse Amber Vinson visited Coming Attractions Bridal & Formal in Akron days before she was diagnosed with Ebola last fall.

entry.title: Liberia calls for Ebola 'Marshall Plan' to rebuild economies
entry.summary:
Sirleaf told fellow regional leaders and delegates at an international conference on Ebola in Brussels that restoring economic growth in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone is a long-term and costly task.

Even if the number of new Ebola cases in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone has dropped markedly, bringing it down to zero will still take a significant effort.

Ebola has undermined the three countries' already fragile economies, shifting resources resulting in other health care problems and hurting business as people grew scared to leave their homes or go to markets.

entry.title: Liberia calls for Ebola 'Marshall Plan' to rebuild economies
entry.summary: "We are talking about a Marshall Plan because Ebola is like a war," Guinea President Alpha Conde said.

entry.title: Report: As Ebola wanes, other countries remain vulnerable
entry.summary:
Some of the travelers checked by workers with surgical masks had traveled through a West African country affected by Ebola, or sat next to passengers who did, and Chadian authorities weren't taking any chances.

It found that 28 countries were worse off than Liberia, which has seen the most deaths from the Ebola epidemic that began in December 2013.

entry.title: Report: As Ebola wanes, other countries remain vulnerable
entry.summary:
The report said only Somalia is worse prepared than Chad for an epidemic such as Ebola.

After causing nearly 10,000 recorded deaths, the Ebola epidemic is waning in the three worst-hit countries, Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.

entry.title: North Korea reopens borders after months-long Ebola shutdown
entry.summary: North Korea is one of the world's most isolated countries and is thousands of miles from the epicentre of the Ebola outbreak in West Africa.

entry.title: North Korea lifts Ebola travel restrictions
entry.summary: Officials in Pyongyang said the restrictions and quarantines would continue for visitors from Ebola-affected countries in Africa and those countries that have borders with them.

entry.title: North Korea lifts Ebola travel restrictions
entry.summary:
"We have been informed by Air Koryo that North Korea's borders are now open for travel and the four-month long Ebola travel ban was lifted as of Monday," Uri Tours said.

North Korean media had suggested the Ebola virus was created by the U.S. military for use as a biological weapon.

entry.title: Ebola survivor leaves US after recovery to return to Africa
entry.summary: Nancy Writebol last summer became the second American infected with the Ebola virus while working at a hospital SIM supports in the Liberian capital of Monrovia.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary:
Duncan, who contracted Ebola in his native Liberia but started showing symptoms during a trip to the U.S., died at the hospital.

On the first day Pham treated Duncan, when Ebola was suspected but not yet diagnosed, she wore a regular isolation gown, double gloves, a surgical mask with a plastic shield and double booties.

She says he falsely claimed that the hospital was trained to manage Ebola and that he misrepresented the type of protective equipment that nurses wore while caring for Duncan.

Varga testified that as the Ebola epidemic worsened over the summer, the hospital system began educating doctors, nurses and other staff on symptoms and risk factors.

entry.title: UN warns against complacency as Ebola fight enters new phase
entry.summary: But U.N. Special Envoy on Ebola David Nabarro said the fight has reached a "second phase, getting to zero, and it really is the hardest part."

entry.title: UN warns against complacency as Ebola fight enters new phase
entry.summary:
Ebola has infected nearly 24,000 people and killed more than 9,600, according to World Health Organization statistics.

"It's a really difficult, painstaking task," he said in Brussels, on the eve of a major international conference on Ebola expected to draw around 600 delegates, including the leaders of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.

entry.title: Nurse who was first person infected with Ebola in U.S. sues Dallas hospital
entry.summary: The first person infected with Ebola in the United States, nurse Nina Pham, sued a Texas hospital on Monday, saying it did not do enough to prevent her from contracting the deadly virus and invaded her privacy after she was diagnosed with it.

entry.title: Ebola survivor sues Dallas hospital over infection
entry.summary: Pham became a national symbol of hope in fighting Ebola after she made a recovery and was greeted in the Oval Office by President Barack Obama.

entry.title: Ebola survivor sues Dallas hospital over infection
entry.summary: The suit claims that the THR's Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital did not initially provide adequate protective gear for medical staff or instructions on how to treat someone with Ebola.

entry.title: Texas nurse sues Dallas hospital over Ebola infection
entry.summary: "I was hoping that THR would be more open and honest about everything that happened at the hospital, and the things they didn't do that led to me getting infected with Ebola. But that didn't happen and I felt I was left with no choice but to turn to the courts for help," Pham said in a statement.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary:
He died, while Pham and another nurse who contracted Ebola survived.

Pham says in her lawsuit that the hospital was unprepared to treat Ebola cases and that she was an unwitting pawn in its public relations campaign to restore its reputation.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary: She contracted Ebola last fall while caring for Thomas Eric Duncan at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Dallas.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary: "I was hoping that THR would be more open and honest about everything that happened at the hospital, and the things they didn't do that led to me getting infected with Ebola," she said.

entry.summary: Another nurse who treated Mr Duncan, Amber Vinson, also became infected with Ebola and recovered.

entry.title: Nurse Treated For Ebola To Sue Texas Hospital
entry.summary:
Pham's patient, Thomas Eric Duncan, was the first person in the United States diagnosed with Ebola.

Duncan contracted Ebola in Liberia and later traveled to Dallas.

entry.title: Ebola nurse Nina Pham sues Texas hospital company
Sierra Leone's Samuel Sam-Sumana in quarantine over Ebola worries
entry.summary:
Despite his quarantine, Sam-Sumana is set to become acting president later Sunday when President Ernest Bai Koroma leaves Sierra Leone to attend a EU conference on Ebola in Belgium.

Sam-Sumana voluntarily decided to quarantine himself for 21 days following the death from Ebola last Tuesday of one of his security personnel, according to the Sierra Leone Broadcasting Corporation.

Sam-Sumana's dramatic quarantine comes as Sierra Leone is experiencing a rise in new Ebola cases which prompted President Ernest Bai Koroma to reinstate restrictions on Saturday.

entry.title: Leaders of Ebola Fight at U.N. Express Worry About Eradication
entry.summary: "This is not what you want to see with Ebola," Dr. Aylward said.

entry.title: Liberia lifts Ebola curfew and re-opens borders
WHO official concerned as decline in Ebola cases levels off
entry.summary: The United Nations has said 10 times fewer people are being diagnosed with Ebola each week than in September.

entry.title: Liberia to end Ebola curfew, open land border crossings
Liberia to end Ebola curfew, open land border crossings
entry.summary: Once the center of the worst Ebola outbreak in history, Liberia has recorded more than 9,000 confirmed, suspected and probable cases and 3,900 deaths.

entry.title: Liberia to end Ebola curfew, open land border crossings
entry.summary: In a statement, the White House said President Barack Obama and Sirleaf would discuss the current Ebola response and the region's economic recovery plans during their Feb. 27 meeting.

entry.title: World Health Organization approves 1st quick test for Ebola
entry.summary: Almost 24,000 people have been infected and nearly 9,400 people have died from the current Ebola outbreak, which began in West Africa over a year ago.

entry.title: World Health Organization approves 1st quick test for Ebola
entry.summary: The new test can provide results within 15 minutes by detecting an Ebola protein.

entry.title: WHO gives green light to 15-minute Ebola test
entry.summary: "The new antigen test is not a game-changer, but it is another useful tool in the fight against Ebola," said Ben Neuman, a virologist at Britain's University of Reading.

entry.title: Health24.com | Breakthrough 15-minute Ebola test gets the nod
entry.summary:
The World Health Organisation has approved the first rapid test for Ebola, it said on Friday.

The health charity Medecins Sans Frontieres, which has been at the forefront of the fight against Ebola, had expressed an interest, he said.

"The big fear has been that the market gets flooded with tests of unknown quality, or unknown performance, and with Ebola you need to know what are the limitations. A false positive has enormous implications. So does a false positive," she said.

"If you had five patients with suspected symptoms and you went ahead and tested them and they were all positive you'd have a high degree of confidence that you've got Ebola."

entry.title: WHO approves breakthrough 15-minute Ebola test
entry.summary: It is able to correctly identify about 92 per cent of Ebola infected patients and 85 percent of those not infected with the virus, the WHO said.

entry.title: WHO approves 15-minute Ebola test
Fifteen-minute Ebola test approved
entry.summary: Trials in West Africa suggest it correctly identifies about 92% of people who have Ebola.

entry.title: Liberia leader to visit US, 1st visit since Ebola outbreak
entry.summary: Since an Ebola outbreak began in December 2013 in the West African country of Guinea, there have been about 7,900 deaths, mostly in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone.

entry.title: How a wedding gown designer took the fight against Ebola to New York Fashion Week
entry.summary:
It was her own one-of-a-kind creation - a prototype protective suit for health care workers fighting Ebola.

But first, Andrews got to take the Ebola suit to Fashion Week, where Jhpiego had partnered with the International Rescue Committee and the GE Foundation to present a pop-up lounge on Friday night at the Empire Hotel.

entry.title: How a wedding gown designer took the fight against Ebola to New York Fashion Week
entry.summary:
An email circled campus asking for volunteers to spend a weekend trying everything and anything to improve the safety of the gear that health care workers across the globe wear when treating patients with Ebola.

A look at the advance in the suit design made by Jill Andrews and the Johns Hopkins team with personal protective equipment (PPE) worn by healthcare workers treating Ebola.

The advanced protective suit for healthcare workers who treat Ebola patients is on show during Fashion Week event in New York.

Andrews spent many late nights transforming the suit from prototype to reality, including when USAID presented it to Ebola Czar Ron Klain.

entry.title: Liberia reopens schools as Ebola wanes
entry.summary: Monrovia: Thousands of Liberian children in pristine uniforms flocked back to school for the first time in six months, after a after a closure designed to stem the spread of the worst Ebola outbreak in history.

entry.title: Liberia reopens schools as Ebola wanes
entry.summary:
At the peak, last summer, Ebola patients were collapsing outside overflowing hospitals.

"Authorities in the three countries are looking at catchup sessions and cancelling some school vacations. It will be challenging," said Sayo Aoki, education specialist in Ebola Emergencies at the UN Children's Fund.

entry.title: Liberia reopens schools as Ebola wanes
Liberian schools reopen after six-month closure during Ebola epidemic
entry.summary: Students in Liberia began returning to the classroom Monday after a six-month closure during the Ebola epidemic that left thousands dead, lining up in their uniforms to have their temperatures taken before they could enter school gates.

entry.title: Sierra Leone promises probe into Ebola spending
entry.summary:
The report by Sierra Leone's Auditor General covered the months of May through October 2014, and looked at donations received directly by the government to fight Ebola.

More than 3,300 people have died from Ebola with nearly 11,000 cases over the past year in Sierra Leone, where transmission remains the highest in the world.

As Ebola is being brought under control, Sierra Leone plans to re-open its schools at the end of March.

entry.title: Sierra Leone promises probe into Ebola spending
entry.summary: Neighboring Liberia reported just five confirmed Ebola cases last week and it reopened most of its schools Monday.

entry.title: Liberia schools reopen after 6-month Ebola closure
entry.summary: In Sierra Leone on Monday, the government promised a full investigation after an internal audit found that nearly one-third of the money it received to fight Ebola was used without saving the necessary receipts and invoices to justify the spending.

entry.title: Liberia schools reopen after 6-month Ebola closure
entry.summary:
"I am very happy to be counted among the living and I pray that Ebola be eradicated from this country."

A few, though, remained a bit fearful about returning even though there are just a handful of Ebola cases left in the country that once saw 100 new patients a week.

Liberia has seen the highest death toll from the Ebola epidemic, with 3,800 killed.

entry.title: Liberia schools reopen after 6-month Ebola closure
entry.summary: Nearly 9,200 people have died since the first Ebola deaths in rural Guinea in December 2013.

Sierra Leone Ebola funds 'mismanaged'
entry.summary: Almost 23,000 people have been infected by the Ebola outbreak in west Africa since March 2014.
